I was a business traveller to this hotel for a week. I have to counteract some off the rave reviews I see here and just say that this is strictly an average hotel, nothing special. We got a very good rate (about 15500 yen) so that was good but even at that price I will make an effort *not* to stay here again next time I need to work in Tokyo again. Here are the good and the bad:
reviews.title: Not amazing - Just OK. Problems with Air Conditioning

reviews.text: Good: About 100 yards from a subway stop (of course this is after walking 200 yards from your room to the front door - see "bad"), absolutely top notch sushi bar in the garden wing lobby floor (6th floor) although you'll pay 11000 yen for the omekase which is over priced, stunning 400 year old secluded garden on hotel grounds including a beautiful waterfall that you can see from one off the main restaurants with huge fish in the ponds and feral cats running around, nice view from the top floor restaurant including of Mt Fuji on clear days, Taxis are always available and waiting so if you need one, no problem (though in Tokyo they are extremely expensive). Service is good.
reviews.title: Amazing hotel -- highly recommended

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed March 2009, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: Bad: Air conditioning does not work well and does not remove enough humidity. This is not an isolated issue as my coworkers who have stayed here several times over the last several years have attested. This will drive Americans crazy as we tend to like our AC. The western breakfast in both major cafes are *really* mediocre. About the only thing that was halfway decent were the custom made omelets. Otherwise I didn't have a decent breakfast the entire trip. Hotel is extremely spread out, exactly like Las Vegas. Each major wing of the hotel is about 150 yards apart, and it seems to get out of the hotel you need to walk about 5-10 minutes from your room. If you are dressed in a suit and in a hurry this gets old fast. While the Akasaka district offers some fun restaurants, the general area is very sleepy and somewhat boring. You'll need to get on the subway to do much. Garden wing rooms seem to have not been updated in 15-20 years..
reviews.title: Great hotel, but room rate was only cheap thing there

reviews.text: As a long time Tripadvisor user who was forced to stay here for business reasons, I think you can do better than this place. Keep looking.
reviews.title: The hotel by itself its worth a trip to Tokyo

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed March 2009, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: Hotel New Otani is massive, but beautiful. The rooms were much larger than I'm used to in Japan, and the view from the windows was incredible at night. If you want a great stay in a "mega hotel" with excellent customer service in Tokyo, Hotel New Otani is a perfect choice.
reviews.title: Great hotel

reviews.text: I really liked the hotel room as the King size bed was huge. The room is very clean and organized. The bathroom is quite big by Japanese standards so I really liked it. I also got a corner room on the 33/F so it had a nice view of Tokyo and a nearby park. This was what I really liked about the room. The room was very spacious and the even had a few different types of pillows in the room that I could try and choose to find the perfect pillow. The slippers are also very soft and comfortable. Overall, I liked the room and a great place to rest after a long day of sightseeing and shopping. Staff's English standards were pretty good too. Concierge was very helpful. Checkout is very quick and speedy.
reviews.title: One of the finest hotels in the world

likes.disliked: — There is nothing not to like

reviews.text: My husband and I stayed at the New Otani for four nights. Three nights we were in the Garden Tower and one in the Main. The Main tower is a newer more contemporary styled Tower. The rooms are the same size, but the Main tower rooms have a floor to ceiling window which gives you a nice view. The Garden tower is a bit dated, but still comfortable. When we got to our room, it was on the 12th floor facing the garden and it was beautiful. We even had a view of Mt. Fuji!! Overall, the hotel is a good choice in that it's a good price (230 for garden, 330 for main) and it's about a 7-10 min walk to the Yotsuya train station.
reviews.title: Good Hotel ; Good Train Access

reviews.text: As for the rest of the hotel, the staff was very helpful, attentive, and spoke english. The resteraunts are ok, but we only tried the sushi and the bfast buffet. But, avoid the sushi rest (can't remember the name, in the garden tower). It's below average and a complete rip off. You're much better off going to Roppogi and getting sushi there. As for breakfast, there's a buffett in the lounge area overlooking the garden which is beautiful. If you'd rather have a quick bfast, try the train station (yotsuya). They have a Beck's Coffee shop on street level as you enter the station, that serves a delicious breakfast (eggs, toast, yogurt, coffee or hot choc.) for about 6 bucks!
reviews.title: Loved the 'Top of the Tower' Breakfast

likes.liked: — Breakfast at Top of the Tower
